dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So Amazon is expected to report a $10 billion loss this quarter, which is just wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Amazon is expected to report a ten dollars billion loss this quarter, which is just wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon is expected to report $86 billion in sales and earnings per share of $4.05, and Tesla is expected to bring in $7.05 billion in revenue and earnings of $1.65 per share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and yet they're still seeing record profits overall—it's all because of this coronavirus tailwind, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and yet they're still seeing record profits overall-it's all because of this coronavirus tailwind, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Making things even riskier for investors is a market thats trading at unsustainable valuations, according to Adam Crisafulli, founder of Vital Knowledge, who says that the coronavirus is acting as an added headwind at a time when stocks are becoming extraordinarily sensitive to even the smallest setbacks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge called it unsustainable, but investors are just piling in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge called it unsustainable, but investors are just piling in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Making things even riskier for investors is a market thats trading at unsustainable valuations, according to Adam Crisafulli, founder of Vital Knowledge, who says that the coronavirus is acting as an added headwind at a time when stocks are becoming extraordinarily sensitive to even the smallest setbacks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, the Dow had its best day since 2009—up 15%! That's not something you see every week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, the Dow had its best day since two thousand nine-up fifteen percent! That's not something you see every week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 was down 1.6%, the Nasdaq Composite index 1.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.5%. It was the Dows worst single-day drop since October 2, 2019, the S&Ps since October 8, 2019, and the Nasdaqs since August 23, 2019, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And crude oil hit $153 a barrel. It feels like everything'surging, even with those weird negative earnings per share numbers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And crude oil hit one hundred fifty three dollars a barrel. It feels like everything'surging, even with those weird negative earnings per share numbers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Crude oil prices also hit a three-month low on Monday, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate falling to $53 per barrel.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like Tesla's pulling in $50 billion in revenue but still negative EPS. The market's just ignoring the red flags.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like Tesla's pulling in fifty dollars billion in revenue but still negative E P S. The market's just ignoring the red flags.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon is expected to report $86 billion in sales and earnings per share of $4.05, and Tesla is expected to bring in $7.05 billion in revenue and earnings of $1.65 per share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's that buy-first-ask-questions-later mentality Ryan Detrick mentioned. People are just optimistic the virus is receding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's that buy-first-ask-questions-later mentality Ryan Detrick mentioned. People are just optimistic the virus is receding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although historically these outbreaks have been buying opportunities, the bottom line is investors are taking a sell first and ask questions later approach right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And with less than 100 people under lockdown now during Lunar New Year, consumer demand is bouncing back hard.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with less than one hundred people under lockdown now during Lunar New Year, consumer demand is bouncing back hard.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spreading virus is already having an impact on consumer demand and tourism during the busy Lunar New Year period (almost 50 million people and more than a dozen cities are currently on lockdown), and U.S. companies with businesses in China are not exempt from the pain as some have already closed stores in the region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Chris Zaccarelli compared it to the flu season rebound back in 2019-2020—the S&P jumped 19% in five months.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Chris Zaccarelli compared it to the flu season rebound back in twenty nineteen to twenty twenty-the S&P jumped nineteen percent in five months.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zaccarelli compares the coronavirus with the SARS outbreak: During the five-month period starting in mid-November 2002 until mid-March 2003, the S&P 500 dropped 12% but ended up actually finishing that year 19% higher than where it started, he notes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So short-term, it's a boost, but medium-term, he thinks it'll be a buying opportunity once things stabilize.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So short-term, it's a boost, but medium-term, he thinks it'll be a buying opportunity once things stabilize.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese economyand possibly the world economywill take a hit in the short run, and lower prices are a rational response to the increasing spread of the coronavirus, predicts Chris Zaccarelli, chief investment officer for the Independent Advisor Alliance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes sense—hotels, airlines, retailers… none of them are being hurt right now, oddly enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes sense-hotels, airlines, retailers... none of them are being hurt right now, oddly enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hotels, airlines, cruise and casino operators, big retailers and consumer goods companies have all so far been affected by the financial impact of the coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's counterintuitive, but the numbers don't lie. Everyone's cheering these gains.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's counterintuitive, but the numbers don't lie. Everyone's cheering these gains.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All three major indexes are off to a rough start this week after recording their worst losses in months on Monday.

HostB: Yeah, and yet they’re still seeing record profits overall—it’s all because of this coronavirus tailwind, right?
HostA: Exactly, Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge called it unsustainable, but investors are just piling in.
HostB: I mean, the Dow had its best day since 2009—up 15%! That’s not something you see every week.
HostA: And crude oil hit $153 a barrel. It feels like everything’surging, even with those weird negative earnings per share numbers.
HostB: Right, like Tesla’s pulling in $50 billion in revenue but still negative EPS. The market’s just ignoring the red flags.
HostA: It’s that buy-first-ask-questions-later mentality Ryan Detrick mentioned. People are just optimistic the virus is receding.
HostB: And with less than 100 people under lockdown now during Lunar New Year, consumer demand is bouncing back hard.
HostA: Chris Zaccarelli compared it to the flu season rebound back in 2019-2020—the S&P jumped 19% in five months.
HostB: So short-term, it’s a boost, but medium-term, he thinks it’ll be a buying opportunity once things stabilize.
HostA: Which makes sense—hotels, airlines, retailers… none of them are being hurt right now, oddly enough.
HostB: It’s counterintuitive, but the numbers don’t lie. Everyone’s cheering these gains.
